author: tkstanczak
content: Hi Proto, one of the questions from EF on how they can help with client diversity had only one response from me -> when we test new features would we not prioritize Geth -> otherwise users will always be given a choice of clients that were tested by all the core devs or something that we had to test entirely. Can we get equal treatment this time?

author: protolambda
content: This wasn't about prioritization, just about what's available and has the most test history. I'm happy to run nethermind, but if there is some bug (and it's really really early in the interop process, there's bound to be one), the testnet will halt and not work for others.

author: tkstanczak
content: Yes, so this will help us be equally resilient if our bugs are same important as other bugs

author: protolambda
content: ok, fair enough, we'll run more of the other clients.

author: tkstanczak
content: Also I believe, that someone said that having more non-prysm clients will be critical for successful merge

author: tkstanczak
content: So teku satisfies it, shall we add more lighthouse too?

author: tkstanczak
content: Thank you! üôè

author: protolambda
content: Lighthouse doesn't work yet. I get it peered to teku, but it's not talking nicely to my nethermind node

author: tkstanczak
content: <@!628018527470616606> <@!199273991058227200> looks like we need to spend some testing getting Lighthouse work nicely with Nethermind

author: protolambda
content: I really want all clients in there, and trying my best with communication and extra hours, but if it's not ready or stable enough, I don't like to take the risk of failing more quickly, as then nobody gets to debug much at all.

author: lukaszrozmej
content: we will spin lightouse box and look into it tomorrow

author: protolambda

author: protolambda
content: We're pushing for multi-client as much as possible, it's just not that easy, bear with me. Apologies to Nethermind and others, I agree with the ambition, but it's a big responsibility to setup and host a somewhat stable testnet at all.

author: tkstanczak
content: I understand but I think that if we do not ensure this now then it will skew the network characteristics later as more and more of community members will continue testing the default setup.

author: tkstanczak
content: Which will lead to less stable mainnet transition as not all clients will feel equally confident.

author: tkstanczak
content: And the mainnet transition when it happens will require major clients to be all on board.

author: protolambda
content: Ok, if people are available to help debug genesis, and maybe do a testnet restart the same day, let's do it. Equal split between all clients

author: protolambda
content:
So far, I know the following combinations to work:
Teku-Geth
Teku-Nethermind (did not run this as much myself, was trying to get lighthouse-nethermind to work, but couldn't)
Teku-Besu (very new, no instructions yet, would appreciate any help)
Prysm-Geth
Lighthouse-Geth (at first at least, but then nethermind wouldn't work, needs more time)

For the other combinations, I need more time to get those deployed and running. I'm happy to hand out more keys if other teams can make them work though. What should the genesis distribution be? Can I get a commitment from each team how many nodes and validators they can run, and we can rely on?

author: protolambda
content: In other news, I'm working on an ansible translation of the tutorial multi-client script for public testnet use here: https://github.com/protolambda/mergenet-ansible

author: protolambda
content: For Steklo, shall we just set eth1-genesis = 12 UTC Thu (noon), eth2-delay = 1 day, testnet genesis = 12 UTC (noon) Fri?

author: potuz
content: That's less than 12 hours from now to Eth1 genesis üí™

author: protolambda
content: For key distribution, we can split keys between; teku, prysm, lighthouse, nethermind, geth, besu. And turbo-geth and nimbus either said nothing at all, or said to join a later testnet, but I can set apart keys for them if they like. But assuming 6 teams + me (willing to run any client), how shall we split validator keys? Do all the new teams feel comfortable running 2048 or more validators?

author: protolambda
content: The eth1 genesis is just the block being configured, it's the eth2 genesis that really starts the chain

author: protolambda
content: It's a legacy thing from the delay mechanism and genesis-trigger in eth2. I'd like to set them to equal the same time, but I'm not sure about eth2 clients handling that correctly there.

author: protolambda
content: I'll try the 0-delay thing now, and if that works, we have equal eth1 and eth2 sub-system genesis times

author: protolambda
content: 0 delay seems to work, we'll use it for Steklo then. It didn't help solve the lighthouse-nethermind issue though

author: protolambda
content:
the mergenet tutorial is currently split in several parts;
- the readme, which covers a mix of both docker and binary instructions, for all clients. There is more guidance, but it may be complicated to navigate
- the PR with the new run_multiclient_docker.sh, which does everything to spawn a small local testnet with
- the PR also has a new doc for build-from-source instructions. The intention here is to simplify the rest (either omit instructions, or or only mention docker), and keep from-source apart, for the devs that still want it that way.

author: protolambda
content: The best thing to do is to document build-from-source instructions and run instructions separately, and then we'll fit in the client in the mult-client script after.

author: protolambda
content: Steklo testnet configs and data (warning: we may change it, steklo plans are still a bit uncertain): https://github.com/protolambda/steklo

author: protolambda
content: Will distribute mnemonics tomorrow. I split the genesis set in 16 mnemonics, each 1024 validators. It's easy to re-do if we want to change that. We'll figure out who runs what before or during the merge implementers call.

content: Update; Will tweak fork digest later and update assets, we don't want overlap with local testnets

- The `sigp/lighthouse:rayonism` docker image: https://hub.docker.com/layers/sigp/lighthouse/rayonism/images/sha256-3afecb79260b2af6401fc8b41a28c7ba9c2df0fdf968a6d4476aab2c9ccfc903?context=explore

author: protolambda
content: In current multi-client setup I use my eth2-bootnode utility, which runs discv5 without beacon node. I'll setup one of those and add it to the config repo in a bit

author: protolambda
content: Technically the network can run without eth1 bootnodes. Some eth1 clients enabled tx propagation, others disabled it. I think it's best if we setup the beacon net first. Then if things are running, we can collect the ENRs from the Eth1 nodes and use that as easy bootnodes list. Or does someone want to help with a special purpose discv4 bootnode?

author: protolambda
content: <@796180621814267904> Sure. You can participate already without asking, by running beacon nodes and eth1 noded without validators. For validator keys I just need confirmation how many nodes, which client(s) (to not skew the net too much towards one), and if you've tried the tutorial.

author: ashpool37
content: I think I'll start by running geth and nethermind nodes, one instance each. I did go through the tutorial last week, but I'm yet to test the Ansible stuff. So I think I will decide which eth2 clients to run a bit later today.

author: protolambda
content: I'll allocate 8x 2048 keys. That's 2048 per team. I can share some keys with power-users like artem, or allocate some more in genesis. What do other think? And if 2048 per team is too many, I can run some of those. Eth1 clients haven't been running these kind of bigger eth2 setups, so I'm a little hesitant here.

author: protolambda
content: <@!796180621814267904> how many validators would you feel comfortable to run?

author: dkdkdkdkdkdk
content: what does the number of validators affect?

author: ashpool37
content: There isn't really a strict upper bound. But I think running 1024 or so is a good idea

author: ashpool37
content: Basically I want to make sure there's a presence of a neutral party, but avoid putting too much extra stress on the fragile network

author: protolambda
content: It's the amount of keys you load in your validator client. And more keys per client = more likely to hit 64 attestation subnet subscriptions to cover all = more CPU and bandwidth cost. It's all relatively manageable still, but I recommend new users to try this on a less experimental testnet before deploying a setup this large. Even just the validator key management can catch you off-guard.

author: protolambda
content: Everyone, also keep in mind we were looking to just run a stable net to debug new things against by experimenting with them whenever during Friday. In the past 24 hours we went from 3 stable clients to 7 clients with equal split. That's a lot of extra last-minute devops (and debugging and configuration for me). We'll get the testnet configured and setup today, try a launch tomorrow as planned, but I wouldn't rule it out that the first start doesn't work because of all these changes. It's going to be a challenge...

author: protolambda
content: Ok, will alloc 8x2048 + 1x1024 validators

author: potuz
content:
continuing to the risk of polluting too much this channel, In the Catalyst API:
```
func (api *consensusAPI) AssembleBlock(params assembleBlockParams) (*executableData, error) {
        log.Info("Producing block", "parentHash", params.ParentHash)

        bc := api.eth.BlockChain()
        parent := bc.GetBlockByHash(params.ParentHash)
```
Here `parent`  is being `nil` on every block, so `GetBlockByHash`  is not returning correctly, but perhaps a check for nil here would be useful

author: protolambda
content: Also, I recommend you stop and remove the docker containers of previous testruns, so they don't get mixed up

author: protolambda
content:
```shell
docker stop catalyst0 nethermind0 teku0bn teku0vc lighthouse0bn lighthouse0vc bootnode0
docker container prune
sudo rm -rf testnets/$TESTNET_NAME
```
Something like this. (need sudo to remove testnet dir, since nethermind docker can't run as regular user, and writes files with 0 UID in its mounted node dir)

author: protolambda
content:
<@!755590043632140352> 
1) I've the mnemonic of those accounts + backup. If people send their address I'll act as faucet and try to send some testnet eth via a transaction (if those work!). Maybe we get the faucet itself running, but the testnet itself is a bit short for full infrastructure.
2) The intention is "a day", enough debugging time for clients to try it. Over the weekend I don't expect anyone to run nodes. I'll just keep mine running till the testnet falls over decisively, or if we have new plans. We'll organize some longer testnet once we're through initial testing (and inevitable bugs).
3) Maybe. If someone likes to host a discv4 bootnodes, then add it to the repo. I'll add the addresses of my network-enabled eth1 nodes once they are up. Transaction-propagation is not the main thing to test yet.
4) Yep, deposit transactions would be nice (any transactions and contract deployments are worth testing really)

author: protolambda
content: PSA: lots of people seem to have peering issues, while the discv5 is working. I suspect it's the eth2 client waiting for the eth1 block to show up, which is 0 seconds before eth2 genesis, so it won't peer until the chain actually starts. This is due to the deposit-legacy of mainnet, where it would first fetch all eth1 data, and only then start the network stack, wait the delay out, and start the chain. If you're an eth2 client dev, please review the activation trigger of your network stack.

author: protolambda
content: Previous local testnets would put a delay between the two genesis timestamp values, but since that worked, and we got some confirmation of 0 working, that the Steklo config was also set to 0 like that. That might have been due to shorter time before genesis (like 1 min away from genesis) of the test setup. If we can peer nodes already, before we get close to genesis, that would be nice.

author: terence0083
content:
<@!203220829473996800> curious how do you get pre genesis fork digest?
```
genesis_fork_digest: 0x79f80e5d
pre_genesis_fork_digest: 0xbe18b010
```

Dont we have the genesis validator root already?


Anyway, Prysm is currently using `0x79f80e5d`, i wonder if that's the reason potuz and i cant peer through your bootnode

author: potuz
content: and I don' t think it's the ordering, p2p is one of the first activations on prysm

author: protolambda
content: pre_genesis_fork_digest is the fork digest computed by combining the fork version with a zeroed validators root, instead of the real root. It's just there for completeness. Bootnodes in mainnet used to have it that way.

author: protolambda
content: the bootnode itself is a discovery node. It's not a beacon node. You can get ENRs from it (and we verified via bootnode trace logs those were being queried), but you have to connect to those ENRs. It may be worth debug-logging what it's fetching from the bootnode.

author: protolambda
content:
Also, if you run a node, try:
1. get your ENR via the api ( `/eth/v1/node/identity` )
2. put your ENR in https://enr-viewer.com/ and check if the values look right. Correct port and IP etc.

author: protolambda
content: in eth2 we popularized "minimal" and "mainnet" configs, and some clients don't like to drift away for some of the variables, and instead compile them in (better typing or optimizations). It kind of makes sense, since a lot of the eth2 config doesn't really change much at all. "mainnet" is more like a "style" than an exact indication. We are looking to fix this config situation by splitting configurables from preset-bundles, but that may take a while.

author: protolambda
content:
https://github.com/protolambda/eth2-val-tools
I use my own tooling for this; the `eth2-val-tools keystores ......` command

author: protolambda
content: It boils down to: `eth2-val-tools keystores --out-loc "[output dir here]" --prysm-pass="foobar" --source-min=0 --source-max=2048 --source-mnemonic="[mnemonic here]"`

author: protolambda
content: in the output dir, you'll find the directory / wallet formats of all eth2 clients. Use `keys` or `secrets` when there's not one that's client specific
